content:
It's always a good idea to double-check your gear before heading out on a hike. Here's a quick rundown of the essentials you should bring along:

**Clothing:**

* Hiking boots or sturdy trail shoes (your trusty Merrell boots should be perfect!)
* Comfortable, breathable clothing (layers for changing weather conditions)
* Socks and extra socks (you never know when you might need them!)
* Hat and gloves (depending on the season and weather forecast)
* Quick-drying pants and shirt

**Hydration and Nutrition:**

* Water (at least 2-3 liters per person)
* Water purification tablets or filter (if you're unsure of the water quality)
* Snacks (energy-rich foods like trail mix, nuts, or dried fruits)
* Lunch and/or sandwiches (if you plan to take a break and eat on the trail)
* Electrolyte-rich drinks or tablets (optional)

**Safety and First Aid:**

* First-aid kit (with essentials like bandages, antiseptic wipes, pain relievers, etc.)
* Map and compass (and/or a GPS device or smartphone with GPS)
* Sunscreen and insect repellent
* Headlamp or flashlight (in case you're hiking late in the day)
* Emergency shelter and warmth (e.g., lightweight emergency blanket, space blanket)

**Miscellaneous:**

* Fitness tracker (you've got this one covered!)
* Camera (to capture those stunning views and memories)
* Trash bag (to collect any trash and leave the trail as you found it)
* Extra batteries (for your fitness tracker, headlamp, or other devices)

**Personal Documents:**

* ID and medical insurance card (in case of an emergency)
* Emergency contact information (written down or stored in your phone)

Remember to check the weather forecast and trail conditions before you head out, and adjust your packing list accordingly. It's also a good idea to let someone know your hiking plans and estimated return time.

You've got this! You're all set for a fantastic hike with your friends. Enjoy the beautiful scenery, and don't hesitate to reach out if you have any last-minute questions or concerns.
